qas.question: Technology that is used to implement secure operating systems is one use of what term?
What is the standard of EAL4?
What is the standard for EAL6?
What is an example of a system that meets EAL6?
Which system is used by the Airbus A380 and military jets?
How common are the formal verification for the highest levels?
In the 1980s the Department of Defense used which standards?

plausible_answers.text: a number of progressively more stringent Evaluation Assurance Levels

qas.question: What does Common Criteria refer to?
Which level do many common operating systems meet?
When was the Common Criteria defined?

plausible_answers.text: the United States Department of Defense

qas.question: What is the name of a system that meets the EAL4 standard?
What makes it difficult for systems to use the EAL4 standard?
What is an example of a system that uses the Orange Book Standards?

context: One use of the term "<a0_0>computer security<a0_0/>" refers to technology that is used to implement secure operating systems. In the <b10_0>1980s<b10_0/> <b11_0>the United States Department of Defense<b11_0/> (DoD) used the <b7_0>"Orange Book"<b7_0/> standards, but the current international standard ISO/IEC 15408, "Common Criteria" defines <b8_0>a number of progressively more stringent <a1_0>Evaluation Assurance Levels<b8_0/><a1_0/>. Many common operating systems meet the <b9_0>EAL4<b9_0/> standard of being "<a2_0>Methodically Designed, Tested and Reviewed<a2_0/>", but <b13_0>the formal verification required<b13_0/> for the highest levels means that they are <b6_0>uncommon<b6_0/>. An example of an EAL6 ("<a3_0>Semiformally Verified Design and Tested<a3_0/>") system is <a4_0><b5_0><b12_0>Integrity-178B<b12_0/><b5_0/><a4_0/>, which is used in the <b14_0>Airbus A380<b14_0/> and several military jets.
